data.text:
In the course of my J-Lit travels over the first seven years of the blog, I read and reviewed three books by Kenzabur≈ç ≈åe, one of the biggest names in modern Japanese literature. While that might sound a respectable total (and is probably three more than many readers have managed), let‚Äôs put that number into perspective. Fellow Nobel Laureate Yasunari Kawabata appeared six times, with eight of Yukio Mishima‚Äôs books covered. Eleven reviews of works by Natsume S≈çseki, one of the pioneers of modern J-Lit, have been posted so far (with more to come), and as for Haruki Murakami‚Ä¶ well, let‚Äôs just say that he‚Äôs a frequent flier üòâ

In short, ≈åe has been shamefully neglected, and today‚Äôs post shows just how much of an oversight that has been. Making predictions is always risky, but on the basis of my latest read, I‚Äôd like to think that there‚Äôll be far more reviews of his books here before 2016 draws to a close‚Ä¶

*****

Death by Water (translated by Deborah Boliver Boehm, review copy courtesy of Atlantic Books and Australian distributor Allen & Unwin) marks a return to the world of Kogito Choko, a recurring character in ≈åe‚Äôs fiction, and a thinly-veiled alter-ego. Choko‚Äôs output has slowed down somewhat as he moves into his later years, but two unexpected events combine to galvanise his desire to write. The first is when he (literally) bumps into a young woman, Unaiko, an actress and playwright, while walking near his Tokyo home. The second is a call from his younger sister, Asa, in which she decides the time has come for Kogito to receive a part of his inheritance, a red leather trunk. The importance of the trunk lies in what it contains, important documents which might help the writer begin a project he‚Äôs been planning for decades ‚Äì a book about his father‚Äôs death:

So why didn‚Äôt I go ahead and start to draft the book? Because I realized clearly that I didn‚Äôt possess the literary finesse to pull it off. But even while I was floundering around, not at all certain that I would be able to survive as a young novelist, I remained essentially optimistic. Someday, I vowed, I will write the drowning novel.

p.7 (Atlantic Books, 2015)

With the appearance of the trunk, the time has finally come to begin work on the novel, and Choko sets off for Shikoku to visit the family home once more.

However, it‚Äôs fair to say that things don‚Äôt go as planned. The trunk doesn‚Äôt have the documents he needs, something his sister and late mother suspected all along. Disappointed, he returns to Tokyo where things suddenly fall apart. Kogito has a major argument with Akari, his mentally-disabled son, and before he can make things right, he is struck down by illness. Recovering slowly at home, the writer senses that he may be gradually approaching the end, not just of his career, but also of his life. Does he have time to resolve his unfinished affairs?

The over-arching theme of Death by Water is of a writer desperate to create a late-career classic, so it is only fitting in this meta-fictional world that this is exactly what ≈åe has achieved with his novel. The slow, innocuous start belies the complexity of what is to unfold, a story spanning a whole life (and others before). ≈åe focuses on his country‚Äôs dark history, intertwining his own family background with that of Japan, before turning towards an examination of gender issues and the way women and war are inextricably linked on both a local and national level.

Large parts of Death by Water take place at Choko‚Äôs family home on Shikoku. For anyone who has read his early novel The Silent Cry, ≈åe‚Äôs description of the house, located in the middle of the woods, will be very familiar. There are also echoes of the earlier book in The Caveman Group, a self-sufficient theatre troupe planning an adaptation of the writer‚Äôs final book when it‚Äôs completed. In the vaguely militaristic way the group organises its activities, we see the heirs of the bored youths looking for a project in The Silent Cry, but also of the frustrated locals during the war wondering what they can do to halt their country‚Äôs decline.

Choko has been obsessed by his father‚Äôs story his whole life, haunted by a dream of seeing him float away in a small boat at night, and the absence of his father‚Äôs papers in the red trunk is a severe blow to his hopes of completing his novel. However, slowly other viewpoints of the fateful night do appear; he finally gets to hear his mother‚Äôs side of the story (second-hand from Asa) as well as the testimony of Daio, one of Choko senior‚Äôs followers:

The truth is, Kogito, by the time your father reached the stage of talking about dispatching a kamikaze bomber to target the center of Tokyo, where the palace is, I think he had already resolved to end his own life, one way or another. I didn‚Äôt have the courage to tell you this before, but I never thought Choko Sensei was the type of man who would live a long, uneventful life and die a peaceful death in his own bed. To be honest, I don‚Äôt believe his drowning was an accident at all. (p.309)

These accounts have the effect of stripping the mystique surrounding the deceased, disillusioning the writer. Just what kind of man was his father, really? Has Choko been chasing a ghost all along?

This personal disappointment is eventually put to one side, though, as the story takes on a wider, more political slant. One strand to the plot is of the menace of the right, with Choko senior‚Äôs crazed war-time plot to kill the Emperor merging into more contemporary concerns. As Unaiko continues work on her recreation of a local feminist uprising, it becomes clear that the hard-line nationalists are still influential, willing to get their hands dirty to defend their values.

As the story progresses, this right-wing slant increasingly clashes with the feminist aspect of the novel. Death by Water has a range of strong female characters, most of whom are far more vividly drawn than the main male protagonists. There‚Äôs Kogito‚Äôs forceful younger sister, his wife and even his late mother. Then, of course, there‚Äôs Unaiko, a woman who represents the focus of the female resistance to the mainly male right-wing tendencies. Her battle to stage the play, a recreation of a real-life event in which local women rose up against oppressors, leads to an inevitable clash with those who want the past to stay hidden:

Of course Unaiko is absolutely determined to stand her ground and deal directly with the neonationalists‚Äô catcalls and objections and so on, during the performance and afterward as well. To that end, she added a couple of lines to the battle-cry recitative and tweaked the last line a bit. So now it will be: Men commit rape ‚Äì that‚Äôs nothing new / But countries can be rapists, too. / Women warriors, here we go / Off to vanquish every foe! (p.349)

Many of these ideas can be linked back to an early anecdote, when Unaiko falls ill on a visit to Yasukuni Shrine during her teens. It‚Äôs only hundreds of pages later that we understand, and are horrified by, the significance of the illness ‚Äì and the location‚Ä¶

While these gender and culture struggles dominate the second half of the book, though, Death by Water is still very much a reworking and reimagining of ≈åe‚Äôs own life: as a writer (several of ≈åe‚Äôs own books are attributed to Choko); as father to a musically-gifted, mentally-impaired son; and as the brother-in-law of a film-maker who committed suicide. Choko is a writer preparing for death and starting to wonder what his legacy is, how he is seen. Throughout the book, I found myself grasping to pull together allusions, constantly wishing I‚Äôd read all of his books, as ≈åe borrows freely from his entire oeuvre. In fact, this is Choko‚Äôs fifth outing (with a sixth recently appearing in Japanese), and while Anglophone readers can try his first outing (The Changeling), as yet the remaining books have not been translated ‚Äì which is rather annoying.

Death by Water starts slowly, but by the end, I was racing through, enthralled by the way the writer manages to cover so many disparate themes over the course of 420 pages ‚Äì and come up with a truly stunning climax. This is a book which has you desperate to go back and read the writer‚Äôs back catalogue, and it‚Äôs hard to come up with higher praise than that. Yes, I‚Äôve definitely neglected ≈åe a little over the years, but if Death by Water proves anything it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs never too late to make up for lost time‚Ä¶
